''Japonés Cubano'' |population = As of 2010:[http://www.mofa.go.jp/mofaj/area/cuba/data.html キューバ共和国基礎データ]
80 Japanese nationals
Roughly 1,100 people of Japanese descent |popplace = [[Havana]] |langs = [[Cuban Spanish]], [[Japanese language|Japanese]] |related = [[Japanese diaspora]] }} '''Japanese Cubans''' are [[Cuban people|Cuban]] citizens of [[Japanese people|Japanese]] ancestry. == History == The group of Japanese Cubans are called '''Nikkei'''. The start of Japanese immigration to Cuba was when there was a noteworthy "peak" in immigration. In 1915, it was estimated that there were fewer than 60 Japanese living in Cuba. They established an agricultural society in Carmelina. Later in 1916, 262 Japanese arrived. Most decided to get a job by harvesting cane. But the conditions were very hard for the Japanese, and some returned to Japan. Some made it to the Isle of Youth, where some families established fruit and vegetable farms. In 1926, immigration to Cuba slowed down. On December 9, 1941, after Japan [[attacked Pearl Harbor]], President [[Fulgencio Batista|Batista]] declared war on Japan, along with its fascist allies, [[Nazi Germany|Germany]] and [[Communist Party of Italy|Italy]]. A few days later, on December 12, all Japanese descendants living in Cuba were declared "enemy aliens". Most Japanese Cubans were seized. There was also 114 [[German people|Germans]], and 13 [[Italian people|Italians]]. As of 1943 a total of about 1,200 Japanese had immigrated to Cuba, including about 200 Okinawans. Later, over 6,000 Germans, Italians, or Japanese ancestry were deported to the [[United States]]. Some found new jobs when they arrived. Some worked as cooks, servants, and other forms of support. The prisoners were not released when the war ended. The last group was released on March 1946; over six months after Japan surrendered. After World War II, some left for Japan. Friendship between the two countries provided women to build a new community. During the 1959 revolution, and the Cuban revolution, more nikkei left for Japan. Today it is estimated that 1,100 Japanese descendants live in Cuba; they make up 0.01% of the population. In 2008, the Japanese government conferred the [[Order of the Rising Sun|Order of the Rising Sun with gold and silver rays]] on Francisco Shinichi Miyasaka Machida in recognition of his contribution to the welfare of the descendants of Japanese emigrants in Cuba.[[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Japan)]]: [http://www.mofa.go.jp/ICSFiles/afieldfile/2008/11/04/conferment_2008_autumn.pdf ''2008 Autumn Conferment of Decorations on Foreign Nationals,'' p. 8.] ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== * Masterson, Daniel M and Sayaka Funada-Classen. (2003). [https://books.google.com/books?id=0FeqfIcY358C&dq=nisei+in+cuba&source=gbs_summary_s&cad=0 ''The Japanese in Latin America.''] Urbana: [[University of Illinois Press]]. {{ISBN|978-0-252-07144-7}} == External links == * [http://www.discovernikkei.org/wiki/Cuba Japanese migrants and their descendants - Cuba] * [http://www.discovernikkei.org/en/ Japanese migrants and their descendants worldwide] * [http://web.gc.cuny.edu/bildnercenter/publications/documents/Masaaki-Tokota25_000.pdf Japanese and Okinawans in Cuba] {{Ethnic groups in Cuba}} {{Cuba topics |DP}} {{Japanese diaspora}} [[Category:Asian Cuban]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Cuba]] [[Category:Japanese Caribbean]] [[Category:Japanese diaspora by country|Cuba]] [[Category:Japanese Latin American]] [[Category:Cuban people of Japanese descent| ]]

{{about|the people|the language|Khoekhoe language|the Khoikhoi dog|Africanis}} {{Redirect|Khoi}} {{EngvarB|date=November 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2017}} [[File:Sameul Daniell - Kora-Khokhoi preparing to move - 1805.jpg|thumb|Nomadic Khoikhoi dismantling their huts, aquatint by [[Samuel Daniell]] (1805).]] The '''Khoikhoi'''{{efn|This is the native self-designation, ''{{lang|naq|khoe-khoe}}'' "men of men" or "proper humans", as it were, from ''{{lang|naq|khoe}}'' "human being".<ref name=Hahn>"The old Dutch also did not know that their so-called Hottentots formed only one branch of a wide-spread race, of which the other branch divided into ever so many tribes, differing from each other totally in language [...] While the so-called Hottentots called themselves Khoikhoi (men of men, ''i.e.'' men ''par excellence''), they called those other tribes ''Sā'', the Sonqua of the Cape Records [...] We should apply the term ''Hottentot'' to the whole race, and call the two families, each by the native name, that is the one, the ''Khoikhoi'', the so-called ''Hottentot proper''; the other the ''Sān'' (''Sā'') or ''Bushmen''." Theophilus Hahn, ''Tsuni-||Goam: The Supreme Being to the Khoi-Khoi'' (1881), p. 3.</ref>}} (updated orthography '''Khoekhoe''', from [[Khoekhoegowab]] ''Khoekhoen'' [kxʰoekxʰoen]; formerly also ''[[Hottentot (racial term)|Hottentots]]''<ref name=Hottentot>"Hottentot, n. and adj." ''OED Online'', Oxford University Press, March 2018, www.oed.com/view/Entry/88829. Accessed 13 May 2018. Citing G. S. Nienaber, 'The origin of the name “Hottentot” ', ''African Studies'', 22:2 (1963), 65-90, {{DOI|10.1080/00020186308707174}}. See also {{cite web|title= Report of the South African Association for the Advancement of Science |url= https://archive.org/stream/southafricanjour14sout#page/188/mode/2up|accessdate= 5 July 2010|author= Rev. Prof Johannes Du Plessis, B.A., B.D. |pages= 189–193|year= 1917}}. {{cite book|last=Strobel|first=Christoph|title=The Testing Grounds of Modern Empire: The Making of Colonial Racial Order in the American Ohio Country and the South African Eastern Cape, 1770s–1850s|publisher=Peter Lang|year=2008|chapter=A Note on Terminology|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eIJtFPirzr8C&pg=PA158}} {{cite book|last1=Desmond|first1=Adrian|first2=James|last2=Moore|title=Darwin's Sacred Cause: How a Hatred of Slavery Shaped Darwin's Views on Human Evolution|publisher=Houghton Mifflin Harcourt|year=2014|chapter=Living in Slave Countries|page=103|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VTNIBQAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=Darwin%27s+Sacred+Cause:+How+a+Hatred+of+Slavery+Shaped+Darwin%27s+Views&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwigq_qNr5TVAhVmrFQKHZjCAE4Q6AEIKDAA#v=onepage&q=Darwin%27s%20Sacred%20Cause%3A%20How%20a%20Hatred%20of%20Slavery%20Shaped%20Darwin%27s%20Views&f=false}}{{cite book|editor=Jeremy I. Levitt|title=Black Women and International Law|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2015|chapter=Female "things" in international law|page=291|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=x08QCAAAQBAJ&pg=PR15&dq=Black+Women+and+International+Law&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiUnL_jr5TVAhWHs1QKHRCtDXkQ6AEIKDAA#v=onepage&q=Black%20Women%20and%20International%20Law&f=false}} {{cite web|url= http://web.mit.edu/racescience/in_media/baartman/baartman_m&g_june95.htm |title= Bring Back the 'Hottentot Venus' |publisher= Web.mit.edu |date= 15 June 1995 |accessdate= 13 August 2012}} {{cite encyclopedia |title= Hottentot|encyclopedia= American Heritage Dictionary of the English Language|year= 2011|edition=Fifth |publisher= Houghton Mifflin|location=Boston|url=https://www.ahdictionary.com/word/search.html?q=Hottentot}} {{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/1957240.stm|title='Hottentot Venus' goes home|date=29 April 2002|publisher=BBC News |access-date=13 August 2017}}</ref>) are the traditionally [[Nomads|nomadic pastoralist]] non-Bantu indigenous population of southwestern Africa. They are grouped with the [[hunter-gatherer]] ''[[San people|San]]'' under the compound term ''[[Khoisan]]''.<ref name="Barnard1992"/>
While it is clear that the presence of the Khoikhoi in southern Africa predates the [[Bantu expansion]], it is not certain by how much, possibly in the [[Late Stone Age]], or displaced by the Bantu expansion to Southeastern Africa.<ref name="Barnard1992">{{cite book|author=Alan Barnard|title=Hunters and Herders of Southern Africa: A Comparative Ethnography of the Khoisan Peoples|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2nBx83jMc48C|date=1992|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=New York; Cambridge|isbn=978-0-521-42865-1}}</ref> The Khoikhoi maintained large herds of [[Nguni cattle]] in the [[Dutch Cape Colony|Cape region]] at the time of [[History of South Africa (1652–1815)#Arrival of the Dutch|Dutch colonisation]] in the 17th century. Their nomadic pastoralism was mostly discontinued in the 19th to 20th century.<ref> {{cite book | last1 = Richards | first1 = John F. | author-link1 = John F. Richards | chapter = 8: Wildlife and Livestock in South Africa | title = The Unending Frontier: An Environmental History of the Early Modern World | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=i85noYD9C0EC | series = California World History Library | volume = 1 | location = Berkeley, California | publisher = University of California Press | publication-date = 2003 | page = 296 | isbn = 9780520939356 | access-date = 17 November 2016 | quote = The nomadic pastoral{{Citation needed|date=July 2018}} Khoikhoi kraals were dispersed and their organization and culture broken. However, their successors, the ''trekboers'' and their Khoikhoi servants, managed flocks and herds similar to those of the Khoikhois. The ''trekboers'' had adapted to African-style, extensive pastoralism in this region. In order to obtain optimal pasture for their animals, early settlers imitated the Khoikhoi seasonal transhumance movements and those observed in the larger wild herbivores. }} </ref>
Their [[Khoekhoe language]] is related to certain dialects spoken by foraging [[San people|''San'' peoples]] of the Kalahari, such as the [[Khwe language|Khwe]] and [[Tshwa language|Tshwa]], forming the [[Khoe languages|Khoe]] language family. The two main Khoikhoi subdivisions today are the [[Nama people]] of Namibia, Botswana and South Africa (with numerous subtribes) and the [[Damara people|Damara]] of Namibia. Their total number is estimated at close to 300,000 people.{{year needed|date=May 2018}}
The [[Griqua people]] are a mixed-raced population in South Africa, of partial Khoikhoi and partial European ancestry. They developed their own ethnic identity in the 19th century and settled in ''[[Griqualand]]''.
==History== {{unreferenced section|date=January 2012}} {{mergefrom|Hottentot (racial term)|date=May 2018}} [[File:Hombre khoikhoi.jpg|thumb|upright|A Khoikhoi man]]
===Early history=== The Khoikhoi, originally part of a pastoral culture and language group to be found across Southern Africa, originated in the northern area of modern [[Botswana]]. This ethnic group steadily migrated southward, eventually reaching the Cape approximately 2,000 years ago. Khoikhoi subgroups include the [[Nama people|Namaqua]] to the west, the Korana of mid-South Africa, and the Khoikhoi in the south. Their husbandry of sheep, goats and cattle grazing in fertile valleys across the region provided a stable, balanced diet, and allowed the Khoikhoi to live in larger groups in a region previously occupied by the [[San people|San]], who were subsistence hunter-gatherers. [[Bantu expansion|Advancing Bantu]] in the 3rd century AD encroached on the Khoikhoi territory, pushing them into more arid areas. There was some intermarriage between migratory Khoi bands living around what is today [[Cape Town]] and the San. But the two groups remained culturally distinct, as the Khoikhoi continued to graze livestock and the San to subsist on hunting-gathering.
===Arrival of Europeans=== The Khoi first encountered [[Portuguese discoveries|Portuguese]] explorers and merchants around AD 1500. The ongoing encounters were often violent. Local population dropped after the Khoi were exposed to [[smallpox]] by Europeans, who carried it as an endemic disease. The Khoi suffered high mortality as they had no acquired immunity to the new infectious disease. The Khoi waged more frequent attacks against Europeans when the [[Dutch East India Company]] enclosed traditional grazing land for farms. Over the following century, the Khoi were steadily driven off their land, which effectively ended their traditional life.
Khoikhoi social organisation was profoundly damaged and, in the end, destroyed by colonial expansion and land seizure from the late 17th century onwards. As social structures broke down, some Khoikhoi people settled on farms and became bondsmen (bondservants) or farm workers; others were incorporated into existing clan and family groups of the [[Xhosa people|Xhosa]] people. Georg Schmidt, a [[Moravian Church|Moravian]] Brother from [[Herrnhut]], Saxony, now Germany, founded [[Genadendal]] in 1738, which was the first mission station in southern Africa,<ref>''The Pear Tree Blossoms'', Bernhard Krueger, Hamburg, Germany</ref> among the Khoi people in Baviaanskloof in the [[Riviersonderend Mountains]].
[[File:Adam Kok III - Griqua Captain - 1848.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Adam Kok, leader of the Griqua nation]]
===Griqua=== {{See also|Griqua people}} Early European settlers sometimes intermarried with indigenous Khoikhoi women, resulting in a sizeable [[mixed-race]] population now known as the Griqua. They were known at the time as "[[Baster]]s" and in some instances are still so called, e. g., the [[Bosluis Basters]] of the [[Richtersveld]] and the Baster community of [[Rehoboth, Namibia]].
Another group were the Griqua. Like other mixed-race peoples and the Khoikhoi, they left the [[Cape Colony]] and migrated into the interior. Responding to the influence of missionaries, they formed the states of [[Griqualand West]] and [[Griqualand East]]; these were later absorbed into the [[Cape Colony]] of the [[British Empire]].
===Kat River settlement (1829–1856) and the Khoi in the Cape Colony=== [[File:Kat River Khoi - Cape Colony 1800s.jpg|thumb|Khoi marksmen played a key role in the [[Xhosa Wars|Cape Frontier Wars]]]] By the early 1800s, the remaining Khoi of the Cape Colony suffered from restricted civil rights and discriminatory laws on land ownership. With this pretext, the powerful Commissioner General of the Eastern Districts, [[Andries Stockenstrom]], facilitated the creation of the "Kat River" Khoi settlement near the eastern frontier of the Cape Colony. The more cynical motive was probably to create a buffer-zone on the Cape's frontier, but the extensive fertile land in the region allowed the Khoi to own their land and build communities in peace. The settlements thrived and expanded, and Kat River quickly became a large and successful region of the Cape that subsisted more or less autonomously. The people were predominantly [[Afrikaans language|Afrikaans-speaking]] Gonaqua Khoi, but the settlement also began to attract other Khoi, Xhosa and mixed-race groups of the Cape.
The Khoi were known at the time for being very good marksmen, and were often invaluable allies of the Cape Colony in its [[Xhosa Wars|frontier wars]] with the neighbouring [[Xhosa people|Xhosa]]. In the [[Xhosa Wars|Seventh Frontier War]] (1846–1847) against the Gcaleka Xhosa, the Khoi gunmen from Kat River distinguished themselves under their leader [[Andries Botha]] in the assault on the "[[Amatola Mountains|Amatola]] fastnesses". (The young [[John Molteno]], later Prime Minister, led a mixed Commando in the assault, and later praised the Khoi as having more bravery and initiative than most of his white soldiers.)<ref>{{cite book| first= P. A. |last= Molteno |title= The life and times of Sir John Charles Molteno, K. C. M. G., First Premier of Cape Colony, Comprising a History of Representative Institutions and Responsible Government at the Cape |location= London |publisher= Smith, Elder & Co. |year=1900}}</ref>
However harsh laws were still implemented in the Eastern Cape, to encourage the Khoi to leave their lands in the Kat River region and to work as labourers on white farms. The growing resentment exploded in 1850. When the [[Xhosa people|Xhosa]] rose against the [[Cape Colony|Cape Government]], large numbers of Khoi joined the Xhosa rebels for the first time.<ref name=oster>{{cite book |last=Osterhammel |first=Jürgen |authorlink=Jürgen Osterhammel |translator=Patrick Camiller |title=The Transformation of the World: A Global History of the Nineteenth Century |publisher=[[Princeton University Press]] |location=[[Princeton, New Jersey]]; [[Oxford]] |year=2015|ISBN =9780691169804|pages=251}}</ref> After the defeat of the rebellion and the granting of representative government to the Cape Colony in 1853, the new Cape Government endeavoured to grant the Khoi political rights to avert future racial discontent. Attorney General William Porter was famously quoted as saying that he "would rather meet the Hottentot at the hustings, voting for his representative, than meet him in the wilds with his gun upon his shoulder".<ref>{{cite book| editor-last= Vail |editor-first= Leroy |title=The Creation of Tribalism in Southern Africa |location= Berkeley |publisher= University of California Press |year=1989 |url= http://ark.cdlib.org/ark:/13030/ft158004rs/ | isbn= 0520074203 |accessdate= 7 April 2015}}</ref> Thus, the government enacted the [[Cape Qualified Franchise|Cape franchise]] in 1853, which decreed that all male citizens meeting a low property test, regardless of colour, had the right to vote and to seek election in Parliament. However, this non-racial principle was eroded in the late 1880s by a literacy test, and later abolished by the Apartheid Government.<ref>{{cite web| url= http://hsf.org.za/resource-centre/hsf-briefs/a-long-walk-to-universal-franchise-in-south-africa-1 | title= A Long Walk To Universal Franchise in South Africa| first= Ashleigh |last= Fraser |date= 3 June 2013| publisher= HSF.org.za | accessdate= 7 April 2015}}</ref>
[[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 146-1981-157-15, Deutsch-Südwestafrika, Kriegsgefangene.jpg|thumb|Khoikhoi prisoners of war in [[German South-West Africa]], 1904]]
===Massacres in German South-West Africa=== {{See also|Herero and Namaqua genocide}} From 1904 to 1907, the Germans took up arms against the Khoikhoi group living in what was then [[German South-West Africa]], along with the [[Herero people|Herero]]. Over 10,000 Nama, more than half of the total Nama population at the time, may have died in the conflict. This was the single greatest massacre ever witnessed by the Khoikhoi people.<ref name=sarkin>Jeremy Sarkin-Hughes (2008) ''Colonial Genocide and Reparations Claims in the 21st Century: The Socio-Legal Context of Claims under International Law by the Herero against Germany for Genocide in Namibia, 1904–1908'', p. 142, Praeger Security International, Westport, Conn. {{ISBN|978-0-313-36256-9}}</ref><ref name=moses>{{cite book | authors = Moses, A. Dirk | year = 2008 | title = Empire, Colony, Genocide: Conquest, Occupation and Subaltern Resistance in World History | location = New York | publisher = Berghahn Books | isbn = 9781845454524}}</ref>
==Culture== ===Religion=== The [[Khoikhoi mythology|religious mythology of the Khoikhoi]] gives special significance to the [[Moon]], which may have been viewed as the physical manifestation of a supreme being associated with heaven. [[Khoikhoi mythology#Tsui/Tsui'goab|Tsui'goab]] is also believed to be the creator and the guardian of health, while [[Gunab (god)|Gunab]] is primarily an evil being, who causes sickness or death.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://khoisan.org/religion.htm|title=Reconstructing the Past – the Khoikhoi: Religion and Nature}}</ref> Many Khoikhoi have converted to Christianity and [[Islam in Namibia|Nama Muslim]]s make up a large percentage of the Namibia's Muslims.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://archive.islamonline.net/?p=18129|title=Islam in Namibia, making an impact|publisher=Islamonline.net}}</ref>
===World Heritage=== [[UNESCO]] has recognised Khoikhoi culture through its inscription of the [[Richtersveld]] as a [[World Heritage Site]]. This important area is the only place where [[transhumance]] practices associated with the culture continue to any great extent.
The [[International Astronomical Union]] named the primary component of the [[binary star]] [[Mu1 Scorpii|Mu¹ Scorpii]] after the traditional Khoikhoi name ''Xami di mura'' ('eyes of the lion').<ref name="iau1707">{{cite press release |url=https://www.iau.org/news/pressreleases/detail/iau1707/ |title=IAU Approves 86 New Star Names From Around the World |publisher=IAU.org |date=11 December 2017}}</ref>

{{Kidnapping}} '''Kidnapping in China''' has its history since the ancient times. Such issues have been heavily studied and discussed by investigators and researchers.
Since at least the 1980s, kidnapping has become a bigger issue than ever in the country.<ref name="foreignpolicy1"/> Since the 1990s, tougher laws against the kidnapping have been established. Chinese authorities have also investigated in this regard.
==History==
Ancient Chinese text indicates the ransoming of hostages during the reign of [[Xia Dynasty]] (2070 BCE - 1600 BCE), they refer to the taking of princes and family members as hostages across the multiple dynastic periods as warrantor of negotiated treaties.<ref>{{cite book|title=Kidnap for Ransom: Resolving the Unthinkable|page=3|first=Richard P.|last=Wright|publisher=CRC Press|year=2009}}</ref>
There have been number of historical incidents of kidnapping in China, In 1523, when two Japanese rival delegations had arrived in [[Ningbo]], they had looted and kidnapped Chinese civil servants. Due to such incident, the official relations with Japan were not restored until 1539.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Asian Mediterranean: Port Cities and Trading Networks in China, Japan and South Asia, 13th-21st Century|page=90|first=François|last=Gipouloux|publisher=Edward Elgar Publishing|year=2011}}</ref>
During the [[Second Opium War]], when an estimated of 18,000 British and French Soldiers had returned to the coastal forts, Chinese' response included the kidnapping of 38 Anglo-French negotiating party members, 26 of them died in captivity.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Great Wall: China Against the World, 1000 BC - Ad 2000|pages=283–284|publisher=Grove Press|first=Julia|last=Lovell|year=2007}}</ref>
In 2015, the Chinese government launched [[QGDGXQ]], a system for identifying and reuniting freed children.<ref>{{cite news|date=21 September 2015|title=National database opens to bring abducted children home|publisher=China Daily|url=http://en.people.cn/n/2015/0921/c90882-8952940.html}}</ref>
As of 2018, the Chinese government has notoriously kidnapped and imprisoned prominent businessmen including Yang Zhihui, Wu Xiaohui and Guo Guangchang. This is part of the crackdown on "market manipulation" yet critics condemn the actions of the Chinese government stating that they are breaking UN human rights regulations and censoring the freedom of speech in China.<ref name="cnn1">{{cite web|author=|url=https://money.cnn.com/2018/08/24/investing/landing-casino-stock-fall-chairman-missing/index.html |title=Casino firm’s stock tanks as chairman goes missing | CNNMoney |publisher=edition.cnn.com |date=2018-08-24 |accessdate=2018-08-24}}</ref>
==Studies== During the 19th century, [[Johannes Von Gumpach]] had described the issue of kidnapping as "One of the most common crimes in China."<ref>{{cite book|title=The Burlingame Mission: A Political Disclosure, Supported by Official Documents, Mostly Unpublished. To which are Added: Various Papers and Discourses on the Claim of the Emperor of China to Universal Supremacy; the True Nature of Actual Diplomatic Relations Between China and Western Powers; the Position and Influence in China of Robert Hart, Esq., as Confidential Adviser of the Tsung-li Yamen; the Hart-Alcock Convention; the Dispersion of the Lay-Osborn Flotilla; the "New Chinese University"; the Policy of the United States in China; the New China Policy of England; the Western Policy, and the Diplomacy of the Chinese Government; the Massacre of Tien-tsin; the Chung-'ho Mission; the Audience Question; and the Coming War.|year=1872|first=Johannes Von|last=Gumpach|page=453}}</ref> According to [[Francis Dunlap Gamewell]], kidnapping was a common crime in [[Shanghai]]; he noted that kidnappers were mostly female.<ref>{{cite book|title=Dangerous Pleasures: Prostitution and Modernity in Twentieth-century Shanghai|page=466|first=Gail|last=Hershatter|publisher=University of California Press|year=1997}}</ref>
[[Carl Crow]], who traveled to China during the wars, he had described the prevalence of kidnapping in China as "well organized business in China carried out with a large degree of success".<ref>{{cite book|title=Carl Crow - A Tough Old China Hand: The Life, Times, and Adventures of an American in Shanghai|author=Paul French|page=118|year=2006|publisher=Hong Kong University Press}}</ref>
==Prevalence==
Kidnapping has become a growing business in China. Steve Vickers of Kroll Associates has reportedly noted that some common scenarios of kidnapping in China includes the kidnapping for ransom, kidnapping of a foreigner(commonly in Hong Kong or Macau).<ref>{{cite book|title=Entering the Chinese Market: The Risks and Discounted Rewards|author1=John E. Dixon|author2=David Newman|page=90|publisher=Greenwood}}</ref>
===Child abductions=== An estimated 70,000 children are kidnapped in China every year,<ref name="foreignpolicy1">{{cite web|last=Rothkopf |first=David |url=https://foreignpolicy.com/articles/2011/10/06/china_missing_children |title=China's Missing Children |publisher=Foreignpolicy.com |date= |accessdate=2014-04-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://usa.chinadaily.com.cn/epaper/2013-08/23/content_16916550.htm |title=The heartbreak of child abduction|Across America|chinadaily.com.cn |publisher=Usa.chinadaily.com.cn |date=2013-08-23 |accessdate=2014-05-22}}</ref><ref name="globalpost1">{{cite web|url=http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/regions/asia-pacific/china/131002/China-child-abductions-reunion |title=For sale: Chinese babies and children |publisher=GlobalPost |date=2013-10-03 |accessdate=2014-04-12}}</ref> although the Chinese government reported fewer than 10,000 kidnappings. According to the [[United States Department of State]], estimates are closer to 20,000.<ref name="foreignpolicy1"/>
Some children are reported to have been sold into adoption overseas. The adoption agencies of China receive considerable donations from foreign parents when they adopt, sometimes as much as $5,000; such agencies have been known to purchase children from human traffickers, although such cases are usually rare.<ref name="foreignpolicy1"/>
===Kidnapping of foreign businessmen===
In [[Guangdong]], during the year 1994, the "economic crimes" topped the list of criminal cases, about 46 debt related hosted cases were acknowledged and investigated by the authorities. The chief procurator, Wang Jun had noted that at least 171 hostages involved in debt-related incidents had been freed by the authorities of Guangdong.<ref>{{cite book|title=Entering the Chinese Market: The Risks and Discounted Rewards|author1=John E. Dixon|author2=David Newman|page=91|publisher=Greenwood}}</ref>
==Crackdown==
From the period of 1991 to 1996, Chinese police freed and estimated of 88,000 kidnapped women and children. During this period, about 143,000 kidnappers were arrested.<ref>{{cite book|title=Decoding International Law: Semiotics and the Humanities|pages=386–387|first=Susan|last=Tiefenbrun|publisher=Oxford University}}</ref>
In 2011, Chinese police asserted that they rescued over 13,000 children and 23,000 women in last two years. Government officials had noted that they would impose harsher punishments on those who purchase kidnapped children.<ref name="aljazeera1">{{cite web|author=|url=http://america.aljazeera.com/articles/2013/9/28/china-rescues-92childrenarrests301suspectedofkidnapping.html |title=China rescues 92 children in crackdown on kidnapping ring | Al Jazeera America |publisher=America.aljazeera.com |date=2013-09-28 |accessdate=2014-05-22}}</ref>
In September 2013, Chinese security forces had rescued 92 children, and arrested 301 suspected kidnappers.<ref name="aljazeera1"/>
According to a report from October 2013, Beijing has tried to combat kidnappings. According to Xinhua news agency, since 2009, police have rescued over 54,000 children and eliminated 11,000 traffickers.<ref name="globalpost1"/>
==Law==
Kidnapping is illegal in China. By 1991, the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress addressed for acting against the kidnapping for sale of women and children, kidnapping for blackmailing, purchase of abducted women and children, as well as the abuse of office to inhibit the rescue of kidnapped women and children.<ref name="Vitit">Vitit Muntarbhorn, The Nation. Bangkok; Section: Editorial Date: 1/7/98</ref>
Such concerns led to the familiarization of a criminal law. Per Article 141, penalties for the abduction, purchase, sale, and trafficking of women and children have taken place. Later in 1997, the penalties were increased.<ref name="Vitit"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.humantrafficking.org/action_plans/4 |title=China - Government Plans - Government of China's Plan of Action To Prevent, Protect, Prosecute and Reintegrate |work=humantrafficking.org |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140812191322/http://humantrafficking.org/action_plans/4 |archivedate=2014-08-12 |df= }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== * [https://www.theatlantic.com/china/archive/2013/07/kidnapped-and-sold-inside-the-dark-world-of-child-trafficking-in-china/278107/ Kidnapped and Sold: Inside the Dark World of Child Trafficking in China] * [https://www.forbes.com/2009/07/28/china-kidnapping-guanxi-leadership-managing-hui.html How To Avoid Getting Kidnapped In China] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120315214448/http://csuspress.lib.csus.edu/sinology/content/ren_xin.html Legal Protections of Women Rights in China]
[[Category:Kidnapping in China| ]] [[Category:Crime in China]]

{{for|the village in Denmark|Korup, Denmark}} '''Korup''' is an ethnic group of forest people located in [[Southwest Region (Cameroon)|Southwest Province]] of [[Cameroon]] and in the adjacent [[Cross River State]] of [[Nigeria]]. There are currently four Korup villages in the Cameroonian side: Erat (a.k.a. Ekon II), Ekon I, Ikondokondo (also spelled Ekundukundu) and Akpassang (a.k.a. Ikondokondo II). The largest village of all is Erat, with an approximate population of ~450,<ref>Röschenthaler, U. (2000). Culture, history and perceptions on resettlement: a baseline study of the six villages in the Korup National Park. Korup Project Study, Mundemba, pp. 108.</ref> and it is located inside the [[Korup National Park]] - which has received its name from the Korup people inhabiting its forests. Ikondokondo used to be located inside the park, but in 2000 it was relocated in the park's support zone, north of the town of [[Mundemba]]. This is why Ikondokondo is nowadays also known as "the Resettlement". Akpassang and Ekon I are very close to, but outside, the park boundaries.
Nigerian Korup villages, such as Ekonanaku, are large but not solely inhabited by Korup people. Many of the younger people do not speak the Korup dialect, although they do identify themselves as of the Korup tribe.
The relationship of Korup villages with the other ethnic groups in the region (i.e. Oroko, Ejagham) is nowadays amiable, and there are often intercultural marriages, especially with the much larger Oroko ethnic group. In the past however, there were frequent clashes between villages of different ethnic groups over ownership of forests.
==Language== The Korup language is a distinct local dialect that is not related to the neighbouring tribes. Cameroonian [[Pidgin]] is used as a local "[[lingua franca]]" between people of different ethnic groups in the region, as is the case for most of [[English-speaking world|Anglophone]] Cameroon. (Note: Cameroonian Pidgin, though very similar to [[Nigerian Pidgin]], it is not exactly the same, although speakers of each are largely mutually understood).
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Ethnic groups in Cameroon]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Nigeria]]
